awd_titl_txt: Conformal invariance and the renormalization group in some critical systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Many models in physics are inherently discrete at the very smallest scale (typically the size of an atom) and there is inherent randomness at this discrete level. At the macroscopic level the randomness is typically not seen. But under certain conditions this randomness manifests itself at the macroscopic scale. This is known as a critical phenomena. For example, the spins in a magnetic material have randomness in their orientation. At a certain temperature these spins can align with each other to produce macroscopic magnetic domains that play a crucial role in technological applications such as hard drives. The randomness seen at the macroscopic scale often does not depend on the details of the microscopic randomness. In physics this is called universality and has developed into a key idea in the understanding of critical phenomena. The renormalization group is set of methods from physics that has become the basis for the modern understanding of both critical phenomena and of quantum field theory - the theory of elementary particles. Despite the tremendous success of the renormalization group in physics, we do not have a deep mathematical understanding of this set of ideas. This research will further the mathematical development and understanding of this set of ideas and methods and use them to understand the mathematics of critical phenomena in models such as self-avoiding random walks and Ising models of magnetic spins.

Most of the research will be devoted to random walk models and Ising-type models. The smart kinetic walk (also known as a limiting case of the Laplacian-b random walk) is a dynamic model for self-avoiding walks. On the hexagonal lattice it is closely related to percolation. Percolation methods have been used to prove its scaling limit is the Schramm-Loewner evolution with parameter value 6. The research will study this scaling limit on other lattices and for generalizations of the transition probabilities. The goal is to understand the universality of this scaling limit. For the ordinary random walk the scaling limit of the exit distribution for a domain is harmonic measure. Another goal of the research is to understand the first order correction for this convergence for both the ordinary random walk and the smart kinetic walk. The research will also study real space renormalization groups for Ising type models, in particular exact renormalization group transformations in one and two dimensions. These transformation have the potential advantage that the map would act on a finite dimensional space. The goal is to prove that the map can be rigorously defined and then take advantage of the finite dimensional nature to prove existence of a fixed point and all the exciting consequences that follow from this existence. Finally the research will study Schramm-Loewner evolution as a renormalization group fixed point. This stochastic process is known to be the scaling limit of many critical models. The goal here is to define a renormalization group map that has this process as a fixed point and then use this map to understand models that are near criticality.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied critical phenomena and the renormalization group with a particular focus on two dimensions. Critical phenomena can be characterized as systems with a very large number of units in which randomness is introduced on a microscopic scale but manifests itself at a global scale as well. In two dimensions these critical systems are typically invariant under conformal transformations. This large symmetry group of invariances leads to a very rich mathematical structure. In particular Oded Schramm discovered a one parameter family of stochastic process which describes many of them. This family is now known as the Schramm-Loewner evolution (SLE). A large part of the research in this project studied various self-avoiding random walk models that appear to be related to SLE. 

One of these random walks is the smart kinetic walk. It can be loosely described as a random walk that never revisits a site it has visited before, but is smart enough to never take a step that will cause it to eventually be trapped. My Monte Carlo studies provided strong evidence that in the scaling limit this walk becomes SLE_6. 

In collaboration with my former graduate student Yan Dai we studied a model that is sometimes known as the mirror model. On the square lattice we randomly place a mirror at a 45 degree orientation to the lattice. (So there are two possible placements.) The walk must reflect off the mirrors in the natural way, so at each step the walk can only turn right or left, not go straight. There is a strong connection of this model with percolation, and this leads to the conjecture that the scaling limit of this walk model is SLE_6. Dai used the connection with percolation to prove that the mirror model satisfies many of the properties that SLE$_6$ has been proved to satisfy. In addition my own Monte Carlo studies of this random walk provide further evidence that it does converge to SLE$_6$ in the scaling limit. 

There are many generalization of this "mirror" model. During the course of the project two different groups of undergraduates worked on some of these generalizations. This provided them an excellent introduction to research in mathematics. 

In collaboration with my former graduate student Jianping Jiang we studied a form of universality that we discovered in the scaling limit of random walks. It has been known for a long time that the scaling limit of the exit distribution (know as harmonic measure)  does not depend on the details of the random walk. I studied numerically the first order correction in this convergence for several different random walk models and found that it was the same in all the models. With Jianping we were able to prove the conjectured form of this correction for a particular random walk model. 

One of the first lattice models which was proved to converge to SLE was the loop-erased random walk. One takes an ordinary random walk and erases the loops in the walk in chronological order. We can carry out a similar loop-erasure for the interfaces in critical percolation. My Monte Carlo studies showed that in the scaling limit the resulting model of curves is conformally invariant with the same fractal dimension as SLE_8/3. But the simulations also showed convincingly that the model is not SLE_8/3, leaving open the obvious question - what is it? 

A large part of this project was devoted to the study of putting the renormalization group for discrete spin systems on a rigorous footing. Most of this research is ongoing. One complete result is for the Dyson-Ising ferromagnet, a one-dimensional Ising model with a power law interaction. Van Enter and Le Ny proved that at sufficiently low temperatures the decimation renormalization group transformation is not defined in the sense that the renormalized measure is not a Gibbs measure. Their proof did not apply to the most important case when the model is at the critical point. For a slightly modified model we were able to prove that the first step of the transformation can be rigorously defined for a class of Hamiltonians which includes critical cases.
